Award.AwardTitle: Tailoring the Surface of Liquid Crystal Droplets by The Self-Assembly of Supramolecular Surfactants for Sensor Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal will investigate whether the presence of target bile acids in a solution outside a droplet of liquid crystalline material (5CB) will trigger a radial-to-bipolar transition in the structure of the liquid crystal, which can then be detected simply by polarized light microscopy.

If successful, this method of detecting bile acids is much easier than existing technique and might be employed in more remote locations where sophisticated analytical tools are not available.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

         Bile acids are physiologically important metabolites, which are produced in the liver for the digestion of fats and fat-soluble vitamins. However, the accumulation of bile acids is closely related to liver disease. Thus, the concentration levels of bile acids have been used as a valuable biomarker for the early diagnosis of liver disease. Although different analytical methods have been developed for the detection of bile acids. However, they often are time consuming and require relatively large sample volumes and expensive instruments. To date, there is still a demand in the development of simple, low-cost, and user-friendly sensing platforms for the rapid detection of bile acids in clinical settings.

         Liquid crystal (LC) droplets are a stimuli-responsive soft material with a large surface area. The adsorption and desorption of chemical and biological species at the surface of LC droplets may change the surface anchoring and consequently induce the director configuration transition of the LC inside the droplets. The stimuli-responsive configuration transition of LC droplets can be simplely observed with a polarizing optical microscope, providing a unique optical probe for the rapid detection of chemical and biological species.

         In the four years of the project, we have developed LC droplet based sensor platforms by modifying the surface of LC droplets with supramolecular surfactants and then integrating them in biopolymer hydrogel sheets. We have demonstrated that the miniaturized LC droplet-based sensor platforms can be used for the real-time and selective detection of bile acids in a small sample volume of biological fluids without needing of complex and expensive instruments, which is highly desirable for the "point-of-care" analysis of bile acids. The response time of the miniaturized LC droplet-based sensor platforms is determined by the hydrophobicity of bile acids and the charge of biopolymer networks. The sensitivity of the miniaturized LC droplet-based sensor platforms can be tuned by the number of LC droplets.

        The project has provided research opportunities for four graduate students. They are trained in an interdisciplinary field of surface chemistry and materials engineering. Work under this project has contributed to 15 journal articles. The general findings from this project have also been presented in national conferences and integrated into graduate courses, which enrich and strengthen these courses offered at the University of Central Florida.
